#Text=2 .
#Text=Laplacian Graph Embedding
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=One-dimensional Embedding
#Text=In this paper , we assume an undirected and connected graph .
#Text=The graph is represented by sets of vertices and edges .
#Text=Given a weighted graph , edge weights are represented as a weight matrix .

#Text=One-dimensional graph embedding finds a configuration of embedded vertices in one-dimensional space , such that the vertices ’ proximities from the edge weights are preserved as the embedded vertices ’ distances .
#Text=Assuming each entry of a column vector as coordinates of the embedded vertices , this problem can be solved through minimization of the following objective function .
#Text=( 1 )
#Text=This function could be minimized when vertices i and j with large are embedded at close coordinates , whereas vertices with small are embedded into distant coordinates .
#Text=In this study , this mathematical property is applied as follows :

#Text=feature classes ( e. g. , land-use category and record ) with a greater degree of object sharing have close coordinates in their embedding space and feature classes with a lesser degree of object sharing have distant coordinates .

#Text=Equation ( 1 ) can be expressed in a matrix operation form with a Laplacian matrix , and can be represented as Equation ( 2 ) . ( 2 ) where , the Laplacian matrix is defined as Equation ( 3 ) with a vertex degree matrix whose diagonal entries are obtained as and the remaining entries are 0 . ( 3 )
#Text=Now , the problem can be changed to find a vector that minimizes , and can be represented as Equation ( 4 ) . ( 4 )
#Text=Since the value of is vulnerable to the scaling of a vector , a constraint is imposed to remove any such arbitrary scaling effect .
#Text=The diagonal matrix provides weights on the vertices , so that the higher is , the more important is that vertex .
#Text=Equation ( 4 ) with the constraint can be solved by the Lagrange multiplier method as in Equations ( 5 ) – ( 7 ) . ( 5 ) ( 6 ) ( 7 )
#Text=Thus , the solution of one-dimensional embedding , , is obtained by solving the eigenproblem .
#Text=However , according to the rank of matrix , there could be more than one eigenvector .
#Text=In the field of graph spectral theory , the eigenvector corresponding to the smallest eigenvalue larger than 0 is the proven solution , which is called a Fiedler vector .
#Text=Thus , the coordinates of vertices in one-dimensional embedding are obtained as components of the Fiedler vector as represented by Equation ( 7 ) .
#Text=2.2 . k-dimensional Embedding
#Text=Now , consider k-dimensional graph embedding .
#Text=These embedded coordinates are represented as an matrix , so that the i th row of , , contains the k-dimensional coordinates of vertex .
#Text=Now , an objective function is defined as Equation ( 8 ) with the constraint , . ( 8 )
#Text=Sameh and Wisniewski proved that the solution to this trace minimization problem is obtained by the k-eigenvectors of that correspond to its smallest eigenvalues other than 0 .
#Text=Thus , the solution of Equation ( 8 ) is obtained by a matrix , where represents an eigenvector corresponding to eigenvalue under the condition .
#Text=However , the constraint normalizes the scales of the coordinates in each dimension .
#Text=Thus , it is necessary to rescale them according to each dimension ’s relative importance .
#Text=Sameh and Wisniewski also proved that the minimum value of in Equation ( 8 ) equals the sum of the corresponding eigenvalues , as shown by Equation ( 9 ) . ( 9 )
#Text=Accordingly , we can assume the eigenvalue as the amount of either the penalty or the cost caused by the i th dimensional space in the embedding problem .
#Text=So , when , it is appropriate to apply more weight to than in measuring the proximity for a clustering analysis .

#Text=Based on these mathematical properties , we determined the embedded coordinates as Equation ( 10 ) , because the increase in distance is proportional to that of the root-squared coordinate difference . ( 10 )
